cluster_relations.rel_desc: Egyptian pyramids functioned as a gateway to the afterlife.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Ancient Egypt: Society, Rulers, and Funerary Culture
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Ancient Egyptian Afterlife Beliefs and Concepts
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ReligiousFunction: transition point to the afterlife

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Food offerings specifically provide sustenance in the afterlife.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Ancient Egyptian Afterlife Beliefs and Concepts
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: wherever the deceased exists after death
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: assuming the deceased can consume offerings
qualifiers.UncertaintyQualifier: implied association between food and sustenance

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Clothing offerings contribute to comfort in the afterlife.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Ancient Egyptian Afterlife Beliefs and Concepts
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
remarks: Specific pairing of clothing to comfort is inferred from general statement.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Jewelry offerings contribute to comfort (and well-being) in the afterlife.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Ancient Egyptian Afterlife Beliefs and Concepts
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
remarks: Comfort effect is inferred, as text does not assign comfort uniquely to jewelry.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Religious texts in the burial are intended to guide the deceased during the journey to the afterlife.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: religious texts in ancient Egyptian burials
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: during the journey to the afterlife

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Amulets placed in the burial are also meant to guide the deceased on the journey.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices and Burials
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: during the journey to the afterlife

remarks: Amulets usually protect; here they are described as guiding—the statement is taken at face value.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The deceased's family commonly employed professional mourners for funerary activities.
Professional mourners are responsible for leading the funeral procession.
Professional mourners carry out funerary rituals.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject functions in the role or capacity expressed by the object.
args.justification: This relation connects the Egyptian pyramids to their conceptual role as a gateway to the afterlife; a generic functional predicate 'serves_as' accurately captures that the subject fulfills the role denoted by the object.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject provides, supplies, or contributes a beneficial outcome or resource expressed by the object.
args.justification: In all three instances, funerary offerings (food, clothing, jewelry) are said to provide or contribute to specific benefits (sustenance or comfort) in the afterlife; a single predicate 'provides_benefit' captures this consistent functional provisioning semantics.
args.remark: Temporal/afterlife conditions remain captured as qualifiers on each relation instance rather than in the canonical predicate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject provides guidance or direction to the object, especially in a ritual or journey context.
args.justification: Both relations describe funerary items (texts, amulets) whose role is to guide the deceased on the journey to the afterlife; the same guidance semantics apply, so they should share a single canonical predicate 'guides'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject engages or employs the object to fulfill a specific role within funerary activities.
args.justification: This relation expresses that the deceased's family hires/engages professional mourners for funerary duties; a specialized predicate 'employs_for_funerary_role' captures both the employment and its funerary context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject leads, directs, or is at the head of the process or group expressed by the object.
args.justification: Professional mourners are described as leading the funeral procession; a simple, reusable predicate 'leads' correctly represents this directional/leadership role.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject carries out, executes, or performs the activity or ritual expressed by the object.
args.justification: The relation states that professional mourners carry out funerary rituals; the canonical predicate 'performs' succinctly captures this action semantics between agent and ritual.

All these relations describe the functional roles of people, objects, or structures within funerary or afterlife contexts: pyramids serving as gateways, offerings providing benefits, texts and amulets guiding, families employing mourners, and mourners leading or performing rituals. Grouping them under 'funerary_function_relation' captures this common semantic family of roles and functions in funerary practice.
args.remark: This class intentionally spans both human and non-human agents, unified by their function in funerary/afterlife contexts rather than by ontological type.

args.justification: Each relation focuses on how an entity is used or functions within a ritual/afterlife scenario—providing benefits, guiding, being employed, leading, or performing. This aligns best with a broad functional/usage dimension rather than pure causality or identity.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject functions in the role or capacity expressed by the object.
executed_decisions.justification: This relation connects the Egyptian pyramids to their conceptual role as a gateway to the afterlife; a generic functional predicate 'serves_as' accurately captures that the subject fulfills the role denoted by the object.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject provides, supplies, or contributes a beneficial outcome or resource expressed by the object.
executed_decisions.justification: In all three instances, funerary offerings (food, clothing, jewelry) are said to provide or contribute to specific benefits (sustenance or comfort) in the afterlife; a single predicate 'provides_benefit' captures this consistent functional provisioning semantics.
executed_decisions.remark: Temporal/afterlife conditions remain captured as qualifiers on each relation instance rather than in the canonical predicate.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject provides guidance or direction to the object, especially in a ritual or journey context.
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe funerary items (texts, amulets) whose role is to guide the deceased on the journey to the afterlife; the same guidance semantics apply, so they should share a single canonical predicate 'guides'.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject engages or employs the object to fulfill a specific role within funerary activities.
executed_decisions.justification: This relation expresses that the deceased's family hires/engages professional mourners for funerary duties; a specialized predicate 'employs_for_funerary_role' captures both the employment and its funerary context.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject leads, directs, or is at the head of the process or group expressed by the object.
executed_decisions.justification: Professional mourners are described as leading the funeral procession; a simple, reusable predicate 'leads' correctly represents this directional/leadership role.

executed_decisions.justification: The relation states that professional mourners carry out funerary rituals; the canonical predicate 'performs' succinctly captures this action semantics between agent and ritual.

All these relations describe the functional roles of people, objects, or structures within funerary or afterlife contexts: pyramids serving as gateways, offerings providing benefits, texts and amulets guiding, families employing mourners, and mourners leading or performing rituals. Grouping them under 'funerary_function_relation' captures this common semantic family of roles and functions in funerary practice.
executed_decisions.remark: This class intentionally spans both human and non-human agents, unified by their function in funerary/afterlife contexts rather than by ontological type.

executed_decisions.justification: Each relation focuses on how an entity is used or functions within a ritual/afterlife scenario—providing benefits, guiding, being employed, leading, or performing. This aligns best with a broad functional/usage dimension rather than pure causality or identity.
